sentences: She also urged Prime Minister David Cameron to take action against Putin and Russia.
It is unthinkable that the prime minister would do nothing in the face of damning findings [by] Sir Robert Owen.
“It is in no sense business as usual” between Britain and Russia, she said, adding that Cameron would discuss the matter with Putin “at the next available opportunity.
Litvinenko had become a British citizen just weeks before his death, a move that he had told friends would protect him from the reach of his jilted former Russian comrades.
The report says he was poisoned twice  —   the first time coming just days after he and his family were granted British citizenship on Oct. 13, 2006.
Owen cited several reasons why the Russian state would have wanted to kill Litvinenko, who was granted British citizenship a month before his death on Nov. 23, 2006.
The two remain in Russia, which refuses to extradite them.

As for the alleged perpetrators, the report states, ”Warrants were in due course issued for their arrest, and the Crown Prosecution Service sought unsuccessfully to extradite them from the Russian Federation to stand trial for murder”.
RUSSIAN INTELLIGENCE Both Lugovoy and Kovtun, who declined to participate in the   British inquiry, have previously denied involvement and Russia has refused to extradite them.
” British officials on Thursday reiterated requests for Russia to extradite the two alleged killers, Andrei Lugovoi and Dimitry Kovtun.

’Former Russian spy Alexander Litvinenko was “probably” assassinated on the personal instruction of Vladimir Putin, a UK inquiry has concluded.’ ’High court judge Sir Robert Owen said on Thursday that former KGB agents Andrei Lugovoi and Dmitry Kovtun poisoned Litvinenko with a radioactive isotope in London in 2006 “acting on behalf of others.
Litvinenko was fatally poisoned by a cup of green tea spiked with radioactive  .

Nearly 10 years after Kremlin critic and former spy Alexander Litvinenko was poisoned with a rare radioactive element and died in London, a retired British judge has issued a report concluding that Russian President Vladimir Putin ”probably” approved a plan by Russia’s security service to kill the former FSB agent.

High polonium contamination was found in the teapot and the hotel bar, and traces of the highly radioactive substance were left across London including offices, hotels, planes and Arsenal soccer club’s Emirates Stadium.

The killers: a pair of assassins who, the report found, were almost certainly acting on orders from the Russian spy service, the FSB, and who left a trail of radioactive evidence strewn across London.
Lugovoi and Kovtun were charged with Litvinenko’s murder the following year by British prosecutors, who found traces of   polonium on their bodies and possessions.

Owen also concluded the two men had unsuccessfully tried to kill Litvinenko two weeks earlier at a meeting at a London security firm, and said it was ”entirely possible” Lugovoy was planning to target him back in 2004.
That fatal encounter came weeks after Lugovoy and Kovtun had attempted to administer   to Litvinenko, Owen says.
” But Owen said the two killers had no “personal reason” to kill Litvinenko.
Litvinenko’s widow, Marina, whose persistence led to the inquiry being held, called for Russian spies to be kicked out of Britain and for sanctions against Russia.

”  [Full report: Russian President Vladimir Putin implicated in fatal poisoning of former KGB operative]  That cautious stance is likely to disappoint Litvinenko’s wife, who called Thursday for Britain to expel Russian intelligence officials and enact new sanctions in response to the killing of her husband.

”’ ’Speaking outside the High Court, Litvinenko’s widow Marina welcomed the “damning findings” of the inquiry.’ ’Russia’s foreign ministry said it would need time to study the full findings of the inquiry, but criticised its conclusion as “politicised”.’ ’Lugovoi meanwhile, speaking to Russian state media, has called the claims “absurd”.’ ’Lugovoi became an MP in the Russian parliament a year after Litvinenko’s death, and thus became immune from prosecution.’ ’Speaking in the Commons, home secretary Theresa May, who set up the inquiry in 2014, described the murder of Litvinenko as a “  act”.’ ’The Russian ambassador to the UK was later summoned to the Foreign Office to meet the minister responsible for Russia, David Lidlington.’ ’Read the inquiry’s full report:’] He fell ill on the evening of 1 November 2006 after meeting Lugovoi and Kovtun for tea in a London hotel.

President Vladimir Putin probably approved a 2006 Russian intelligence operation to murder   agent Alexander Litvinenko with radioactive   in London, a British inquiry concluded on Thursday, prompting a row with Moscow.

Vladimir Putin was furious when one of his former spies, Alexander Litvinenko, publicly called him a pedophile in 2006  —   a slur that likely spurred the Russian leader to order the dissident’s assassination in London four months later, a British report concluded on Thursday.
Lugovoy, now a Russian lawmaker, was quoted by the Interfax news agency as saying the accusation was absurd.
Britain summoned the Russian ambassador for a   and imposed an asset freeze on the two main suspects: Andrei Lugovoi, now a Russian lawmaker, and Dmitry Kovtun.
Kovtun, now a businessman, described the charges as based on “falsified and fabricated evidence,” the Interfax news agency reported.

“The fact that Mr Litvinenko was poisoned with   that had been manufactured in a nuclear reactor suggests that Mr Lugovoi and Mr Kovtun were acting for a state body, rather than (say) a criminal organization,” it says.

Although the inquiry stops short of conclusively blaming Putin  —   noting the opaque nature of Kremlin politics  —   it finds that there is “strong circumstantial evidence that the Russian State was responsible for Mr Litvinenko’s death.

”I have concluded that there is a strong probability that when Mr Lugovoy poisoned Mr Litvinenko, he did so under the direction of the FSB I have further concluded that Mr Kovtun was also acting under FSB direction,” he said.

” Britain immediately summoned the Russian ambassador to express “profound displeasure” at what Home Secretary Theresa May called Moscow’s “blatant and unacceptable breach of the most fundamental tenets of international law.

Interior minister Theresa May, appearing before parliament, spoke of ”a blatant and unacceptable breach of the most fundamental tenets of international law and of civilized behavior” while the opposition Labour Party described an ”unparalleled act of   terrorism”.

” “He made clear that the inquiry’s conclusion concerning the Russian state’s probable involvement in this murder was deeply disturbing, demonstrating a flagrant disregard for UK law, international law and standards of conduct, and the safety of UK citizens,” the spokesperson said.

According to the report, the two men lured Litvinenko to the Pine Bar at the Millennium Hotel in Mayfair on Nov. 1, 2006, ostensibly to discuss a business deal, and served him a cup of cold green tea.
The judge said he was sure Lugovoy and Kovtun had placed the polonium 210 in a teapot at the Millennium Hotel’s Pine Bar on Nov. 1, 2006 when they met Litvinenko for little more than 30 minutes.

From the report: ”The evidence establishes that Mr Litvinenko ingested the fatal dose whilst drinking tea from a teapot contaminated with   in the Pine Bar of the Millennium Hotel in the West End of London in the afternoon of 1 November in the company of Andrei Lugovoy and Dmitri Kovtun.
”There was undoubtedly a personal dimension to the antagonism between Mr Litvinenko on the one hand and President Putin on the other,” Owen’s report said.
Judge Owen adds that there’s no sign of a possible personal motive for Lugovoy and Kovtun, and that all the evidence in the case ”points in one direction”  —   to Moscow.
“There was undoubtedly a personal dimension to the antagonism” between Putin and Litvinenko, the report says.
In Moscow, Putin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said that “such   as we have today, can only further poison the atmosphere of our relations.
The report would “further poison the atmosphere of our bilateral relations,” said the spokesman, Dmitry Peskov.
Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said such inquiries risked poisoning relations and pointed out that the inquiry relied on unpublicised information from the intelligence services.

Litvinenko’s widow, Marina, speaking Thursday outside the Royal Courts of Justice in London, welcomed the report by saying, ”The words my husband spoke on his deathbed, when he accused Mr Putin of his murder, have been proved true in an English court”.

.. calling for the imposition of targeted economic sanctions and travel bans against named individuals, including Mr Patrushev and Mr Putin,” she told reporters outside London’s Royal Courts of Justice.

“I am, of course, very pleased that the words my husband spoke on his deathbed  —   when he accused Mr Putin of his murder  —   have been proved true,” she told reporters outside the Royal Courts of Justice in central London.
“The FSB operation to kill Mr Litvinenko was probably approved by Mr [Nikolai] Patrushev [then head of the FSB] and also by President Putin,” the report concludes.

The inquiry ruled out suicide or accident as causes for Litvinenko’s death, and concluded that he was “deliberately poisoned” and that the murder was “probably” approved by Putin and Nikolai Patrushev, former head of the FSB, the successor organisation to the KGB “I am also calling for the imposition of targeted economics sanctions and travel bans against named individuals including Mr Patrushev and Mr Putin.

“Taking full account of all the evidence and analysis available to me, I find that the FSB operation to kill Mr Litvinenko was probably approved by Mr Patrushev and also by President Putin,” the report says.

An inquiry led by senior British judge Robert Owen found that former KGB bodyguard Andrei Lugovoy and another Russian, Dmitry Kovtun, carried out the killing as part of an operation probably directed by Russia’s Federal Security Service (FSB) the main heir to the   KGB ”The FSB operation to kill Mr Litvinenko was probably approved by Mr Patrushev, then head of the FSB, and also by President Putin,” Owen said.

The report released today by Sir Robert Owen, chairman of the British inquiry into Litvinenko’s murder, concludes that ”the FSB operation to kill Mr Litvinenko was probably approved by Mr Patrushev, then head of the FSB, and also by President Putin.
